newsitem.title: USA: WebTV Networks enters "Java for TV" pact.
newsitem.headline: WebTV Networks enters "Java for TV" pact.

text.p: Web TV Networks Inc said on Wednesday it will work with Sun Microsystems Inc to develop a "Java for TV" initiative bringing new features of the Internet to television.

In a keynote address at Sun's JavaOne industry conference here, Sun executives demonstrated how a WebTV could use Java on a television set to browse through TV programs and select TV channels or Internet pages.
WebTV launched a set-top box along with licensees Sony Corp and Philips Electronics last fall and runs an Internet service delivered over normal telephone lines to televisions.

WebTV spokeswoman Marcy Dockery said the company had co-developed the PersonalJava system Sun unveiled on Wednesday and is the first company to license the implementation, which enables devices like televisions, set-top boxes and screen-equipped phones to run Java.
Java is a programming language popular for use on the Internet which enables software programmers to write one piece of software to run on a broad variety of computers.
Investors in WebTV include Seagate Technology, Microsoft Corp, Citicorp, Times-Mirror Inc., the Washington Post, and Verifone.

Venture capital investors include Asia Pacific Ventures, Brentwood Venture Capital, Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's Vulcan Ventures, St. Paul Capital, George Soros Capital and Lauder Partners. ((sam.perry@reuters.com, Palo Alto Bureau 415 846 5400))
